Robin Milner

Biography and Contribution

Arthur John Robin Gorell Milner was born in Yealmptin, England, on the 13th January 1934 and passed away on the 20th March 2010 in Cambridge, England. He attended Eton College in 1947. After earning his degree Milner followed his family steps, by joining the Royal Engineers, where he walked up the ranks, until Second Lieutenant. In 1957 he graduated from Kingâ€™s College, Cambridge where he obtained a Bachelor of Science in mathematics. After working as schoolteacher and a programmer at Ferranti, Milner pursued an academic career. He was a professor at the City University of London; Swansea University; Stanford University; university of Edinburgh. At the last one he co-founded the Laboratory for Foundations of Computer Science. In 995 Milner became the head of computer Laboratory at Cambridge and later became Chair of Computer Science at the University of Edinburgh.
Milner has given three main contributions to the computer sciences. The Logic of Computable Functions (LCF), the ML and the CCS. For more information about his three contributions, follow the link below.

Awards and Honors
1987 British Computer Society Technical Award
1988 Distinguished Fellow of the British Computer Society
1988 Founding Member Academia Europaea
1988 Fellow of the Royal Society
1991 Turing Award
1993 Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh
1994 Fellow of the ACM
2004 Royal Medalist of the Royal Society of Edinburgh
2008 Foreign Associate of the National Academy of Engineering
Turing Award 1991

In memory of A.M. Turing
